Below is a list of resource links that I share with workshops I do on digital mapping. Some of these are geared specifically to historians, but most are applicable to anyone. Iâ€™m happy to field questions by email if you are interested in digital mapping but are unsure where to start.

Tutorials for getting started

http://lincolnmullen.com/projects/spatial-workshop/spatial-data.html http://programminghistorian.org/lessons/

Web-based GIS apps

https://www.google.com/maps/about/mymaps/ https://storymaps.arcgis.com/en/ https://www.arcgis.com/home/index.html https://carto.com/ https://www.mapbox.com/ http://leafletjs.com/

GIS software

http://www.qgis.org/en/site/ (free and open source) https://www.arcgis.com/features/index.html https://www.google.com/earth/ (free version)

Convert a spreadsheet to something spatial or vice versa

http://www.convertcsv.com https://ogre.adc4gis.com http://www.carto.com

Georeference a list of locations (i.e. get latitude and longitude coordinates)

https://www.google.com/maps/about/mymaps/ http://www.carto.com http://www.latlong.net/ https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/geocoding/start

Georectify a map (i.e. give an image of a map GIS coordinates)

http://lincolnmullen.com/projects/spatial-workshop/georectification.html http://www.qgis.org/en/site/ https://www.arcgis.com/features/index.html

Use your own tiled basemap

https://www.mapbox.com/ https://tilemill-project.github.io/tilemill/

Find more GIS data to compliment your data

http://railroads.unl.edu/resources/ https://www.nhgis.org/documentation/gis-data http://www.davidrumsey.com/home https://geospatialhistorian.wordpress.com/finding-data/

Preparing maps for printing

http://www.qgistutorials.com/en/docs/making_a_map.html https://alexurquhart.com/post/cartography-tips-arcmap/ https://carto.com/learn/guides/publish-share/export-as-image/
